title: The Revelation of Jesus Christ in Scripture Grades 8-12
subject: Theology

document.title: United States Conference of Catholic Bishops

819D2B2F09064713BC937408D20C0107.description: In modern times, there are individuals and groups who try to explain in natural scientific terms the miracles of Jesus, thus undermining his divinity.

FE2465D385D54C9FA5C7BDED87D66B8A.description: Sometimes people did not like what Jesus taught or did or what happened to him. There were a number of “gospels” written, which the Church, under the guidance of the Holy Spirit, recognized as not authentic. Some of these gospels shied away from teaching the Incarnation, suffering, Death, and Resurrection of Jesus.

4123881B597B44579DDE6E97AAEF45C3.description: In the early history of the Church, there were a number of heresies about Jesus Christ which arose when people tried to explain the mystery of who he was and is. An example of this is the Arian heresy, which denied the full divinity of Christ.

31C01165E6FC43E7B51F26B0CEA68C4A.description: People have tried to change teaching about Christ for many different reasons. Sometimes it is to justify their particular belief or lack of belief. Sometimes it has been out of sincere but misguided or misinformed efforts to try to explain mysteries about Jesus Christ or God’s Revelation.

F1A4602F5EB4455EB8F73E3A53330888.description: Why do some people try to change what the Church teaches about Jesus Christ?

FEC5CA032F6D48808FDEBA098A6CEB32.description: Apostolic Tradition refers to those things that Jesus taught to the Apostles and early disciples, which were passed down to us at first by word of mouth and were only written down later. We identify these beliefs as coming from Tradition and understand that this Tradition is part of God’s Revelation to us (CCC, no. 83).

0C23C48353F44651B952987B73644E2D.description: There are teachings that come through Tradition that are not explicitly found in Scripture. However, nothing taught through Tradition ever contradicts Scripture since both come from Christ through the Apostles (CCC, no. 82).

DC9F5CAB97DA45E3902457C7E8A54D36.description: The Bible is not the sole means that God chose to hand on the truths of Revelation. Scripture and Tradition are the two complementary ways Revelation is passed down (CCC, nos. 80, 97).

610A7FC0E3814F9793F3D17DEA894E2E.description: Why do Catholics maintain beliefs and practices that are not in the Bible?

C85A7EF885A94CAE974BEFB8B4BF1539.description: God continues to speak to us through Scripture; this is why the liturgies of the Church always contain Scripture and why personal prayer focused on Scripture is vital.

930947508F0A40E8BFBD7E57E546196D.description: While the Bible contains history, stories, and teaching about events in the past, Scripture is the living Word of God. While the content is rooted in particular moments in history, the message is timeless and universal.

353082113F4C4A6088EB863EDF4F3C21.description: Isn’t the Bible about the past? Why do people today think it applies to them?

735B31A28F664AFA9CFBEF7441801A67.description: The Church gives guidelines for interpretation of Sacred Scripture (see earlier in outline).

78A0CA33AB974E638F3378222CA5C2EE.description: The Bible has a definite historic basis for events recounted in both the Old and the New Testaments; the Church particularly upholds the historicity of the Gospels (CCC, no. 126). However, the Church does not claim that the Bible’s purpose is to present scientific or historical facts (CCC, no. 107).

67D74247D147426BAE646A48402CEB97.description: It depends on what one means by “literally.” The Church does not always propose a literalist or fundamentalist approach to Scripture but rather a contextualist approach. The Church teaches that all of Scripture is true on matters pertaining to religious and salvific teaching because it is inspired by God for that purpose (CCC, nos. 107, 116).

EB376B2AE1CB438DAEB49A78A75250E9.description: Is the Bible always literally true?

A7C9AC27843841F99C992E4F98A0345D.description: Scripture always needs to be read or interpreted in the light of the Holy Spirit and under the direction of the Church (CCC, nos. 100, 111, 119, 137).

BAED59CEDAFB494492E54E93373714A8.description: Since it is not just another piece of literature, Scripture cannot be either read or understood merely in the same way as other literature (CCC, no. 108).

16A85FF4E79A4933A3551CF56967D0FE.description: No. While Scripture contains various types of literary forms and genres, it is more than just literature. It is the inspired Word of God (CCC, no. 135).

D389AA693B534A419C636B07363735C2.description: Isn’t the Bible just another piece of literature?

1D00F63D8F734E8FB94E20033577108D.description: In the fourth century, St. Jerome said that “ignorance of the Scriptures is ignorance of Christ”; this underlines the importance of Scripture in the life of the Church (CCC, no. 133).

C2663061A8E84487A979A6DCB968D9D7.description: Scripture study and prayer groups using Scripture are a common part of parish life.

AE7ACC1B7C514D23BBBC38D780CE1D95.description: The Church urges Catholics to use the Bible in personal prayer (CCC, nos. 2653-2654).

62EA4D3527354DFE8AD3801BCC2D98AB.description: No. Catholics use the Bible regularly. The Bible or Scripture is an integral part of Catholic prayer life, forming part of every Mass, every sacramental celebration, and the official daily prayer of the Church—the Liturgy of the Hours (CCC, nos. 141, 1190).

26E2AB8EDDA6446E8D53EB7B2623B224.description: Is it true that Catholics do not use or read the Bible?

8C1A415CF1DF4F928E4DE86A7FD80BF5.description: Christ’s Last Supper discourse and priestly prayer.

9F39BCF6C0AA4F3AABDE6DD139B61CD9.description: John treats miracles as signs of Christ’s glory/ divinity—flows from John 1:14.

475D5A07BB084B4389D73F4F2EB422C2.description: John uses Christ’s dialogues and personal testimony and is more mystical (CCC, nos. 547-550).

4F8DFE94AA694D9483D21A8CC4F27D27.description: What is known about John. 3. The content of the Gospel of John.

5426BBF6A352491C9BB890E82E311790.description: Approximate date of the Gospel and churches for which John wrote.

D9B23C1F953E412F9690158D7CC0A038.description: Last Supper, the Passion, Death, Resurrection, Ascension (CCC, nos. 1329, 1337, 1366, 1323, 1412, 1521-1522, 1532, 1708, 1992, 2020).

89EC3DEDED51409184159238B26D5DE4.description: Sermon on the Mount in Matthew; Sermon on the Plain in Luke.

A3769496E9C240089B7333E2C10C08F0.description: Infancy narratives in Matthew and Luke.

B107063B67464D20B91035281A66E92F.description: The contents of the Synoptic Gospels (CCC, nos. 512-667).

7B3F364A3D5B4D4B81AFDD60A2FB80B5.description: The churches for whom Matthew, Mark, and Luke wrote.

CDFDCE621482464D9667D70D4476F7A6.description: What is known about each of these three evangelists.

7B4F052F5FAE47EE9B0035612950A034.description: The Synoptic Gospels: Matthew, Mark, and Luke.

0903D3C9E070432690D132BEC218D8CE.description: Three stages in the formation of the Gospels (CCC, no. 126).

60402512B2514E34B01D30E2D43398A5.description: The Gospels lead us to accept Jesus Christ in faith and apply his teachings to our lives.

376C265580BB4C04872AE27D75C2D8E5.description: The Gospels contain a record of the life of Jesus Christ and of his teachings and redeeming work.

456E67DB281E47308F2BB63BEC3C44D0.description: They proclaim the Good News of Jesus Christ, the Word of God, the definitive Revelation of God.

C230561CAC154314A7AC07001DE29DA1.description: The Gospels occupy the central place in Scripture (CCC, nos. 125, 139).

2D6421B462AA44CE81A63302A2F04FF9.description: The unity of the Old Testament and the New Testament (CCC, nos. 124-125, 128-130, 140).

A9EB65D5069446BB8F914CC1DA300D25.description: The New Testament is composed of the Gospels, the Acts of the Apostles, the Epistles or Letters, and the book of Revelation.

AC8FD1A769A34D45B1F4D1F952E2A761.description: This is the name given to those twenty-seven books which compose the second part of the Bible and which focus on the life and teachings of Jesus Christ and some writings of the early Church.

A662BB1331254C9A871B2B2B3ADFEC5D.description: The Old Testament contains the Pentateuch, the Historical books, the Wisdom books, and the Prophetic books.

9085D19425D748CFBF4F4C6C46418879.description: It is called the “Old” Testament because it relates God’s teaching and actions prior to the coming of Jesus Christ, who is the fullness of Revelation. It also focuses on the covenant God made with the Jewish people, which is called the “Old Covenant” to distinguish it from the New Covenant made by Jesus Christ (CCC, nos. 121-123).

898023395AE041C4A98A255C8E399ED8.description: Catholics rely on the Greek version of the Old Testament for their Bible, while Protestants tend to rely on a Hebrew version.

9215FF0473F94DFDADB8718D1F78B017.description: Many Protestant Bibles have only thirty-nine books in the Old Testament; other Protestant Bibles contain the additional seven, referring to them as “deuterocanonical.”

D5410B6844024B139D26AAFB02DA5C22.description: This is the name given to the forty-six books which make up the first part of the Bible and record salvation history prior to the coming of the Savior, Jesus Christ (CCC, no. 120).

1E43432443B7480AB0E288F39F2052C5.description: The forms of literature in the Bible.

56F3B04FB13E4B35802A47C762A7B78E.description: Biblical archaeology: discoveries of Dead Sea Scrolls, Nag Hammadi, targums, and other authentic ancient texts.

6ED37C3AE4EA4577A17377E0C715773E.description: Research done by scholars’ critiques of Scripture’s texts, history, editing, etc.

4D3C22C4A01A4724AFD3436E05B54C2B.description: The difference between the Catholic understanding of Scripture and that of those who interpret the Bible in an overly literalist, fundamentalist way or with an approach limited to a symbolic understanding.

6A0E669297BF4044BD047A20C8EF5560.description: There can be no conflict between religious truth and scientific and historical truth (CCC, no. 159).

63BA63462CC7420AA8530DD39054F512.description: The Church teaches us how to relate truths of faith to science.

BD90B17818DF450A8B565C99ED5EC014.description: The Bible in relation to science and history (CCC, nos. 37, 159, 1960).

122B6DF70414413DB4E035AE1BC30F70.description: Anagogical sense: Scripture speaks to us of eternal realities.

0D3CEEA1CC8C422C9EECEF47D6B8D84B.description: Moral sense: Scripture teaches us and encourages us how to live and act.

BC69B2BBBB484D0B8CF8246EB889AF73.description: Allegorical sense: recognizing the significance of events in the Bible as they relate to Christ

387E68AC63804E08B73C4AC0B503672E.description: The literal sense: the meaning conveyed by the words of Scripture and discovered by exegesis (CCC, nos. 109-110, 116).

BCDAC05484814477B92342C60889B784.description: Be attentive to the analogy of faith, that is, the unity that exists in all Church teaching.

64A256EAE04D4D8C84A0E1DCF3BDE549.description: Read and interpret each part of Sacred Scripture with an awareness and understanding of the unity of the content and teaching of the entire Bible

34CADC9BABDF4A42A04F6CC0E1C49948.description: Read and interpret Sacred Scripture in the light of the same Holy Spirit by whom it was written (DV, nos. 12-13).

8D5614A311C2400398677F48579C56C7.description: Take into account the conditions of the time when it was written and the culture where it was written.

0FB13E8027D249EC91C3D38D3A30E8F4.description: Give attention both to what the human authors intended to say and to what God reveals to us by their words.

61E74B91ED8F44A594F2D5E4BA2E30A7.description: Read and interpret Sacred Scripture within the tradition and teaching of the Church.

2E1BBC548904480ABB155FE36925EA07.description: Criteria for interpreting the Sacred Scripture (CCC, nos. 109-114, 137).

C06AEA0F3CBB4AA189EC786C52A5F401.description: Pontifical Biblical Commission, Interpretation of the Bible in the Church, 1993, nos. 5-19.

6A3CDE8FCA98418F9F8E799FFD1BC733.description: Dei Verbum (DV) (Vatican II, 1965; Church teaching on Revelation).

E5AB1A7E801B40E0AE02DE532E072F31.description: Divino Afflante Spiritu (Pius XII, 1943; permitted limited use of modern methods of biblical criticism).

E49D888E1F1E4E9DA7FBF87EBCDB620E.description: Authentic interpretation of the Bible is the responsibility of the teaching office of the Church (CCC, nos. 85-87, 100).

FE04EF5C5D8741589E074CEB94929BAB.description: Scripture as basis for individual prayer and for prayer within small Christian communities and other parish, school, or local gatherings (CCC, nos. 2653-2654).

C8C5FF8633754492B0E8D92D7437538B.description: Lectio divina: a meditative, prayerful approach to Scripture (CCC, nos. 1177, 2708).

78C230594B1749CD8026B0A2F6459964.description: The psalms and the Our Father are biblical prayers shared by all Christians (CCC, nos. 2585ff., 2759ff.)

F6E3793053974589AB4040EE3F9CD66D.description: Scripture at Mass and other liturgies (CCC, nos. 103, 1096, 1100, 1184, 1190, 1349).

6D4D91C9DC334125A8A30F25F99FE2BE.description: Scripture and prayer. a. Liturgy of the Hours (CCC, nos. 1176-1177).

FB824C6898AA4FBE8851DD465DC45BD3.description: Sacred Scripture in the life of the Church.

1810B18A233A43CD956356D34E28C740.description: Local Councils of Hippo (AD 393) and Carthage (AD 397). d. Ecumenical Council of Trent (AD 1545-1563).

41381428C2DD4576B013BAF19B03A207.description: Sometimes other criteria came into play, e.g., the Gnostic gospels were rejected in part because they did not include or shied away from the suffering and Death of Jesus.

D2CCE40E0A0346BF86E514257A582BFA.description: Apostolic Tradition is the basis for which books the Church included (CCC, nos. 120, 138).

2EE32D1F09564F91B8A05574540B2628.description: Setting the canon of Scripture (CCC, no. 120).

FD78B287CA0D4621BF28C3CFF25DCCAA.description: Development of the written books (CCC, nos. 76, 106).

AADE2AE75FB74EE68E60938F5C9EEEE8.description: Oral tradition and its role (CCC, nos. 76, 126).

BA83148EDCD14E3C9326E9BBF1FFE53B.description: How the Bible came to be.

1EBF294E5BC1450C90D6B353C9D43382.description: The Bible is a sacred text for Christians; it contains in the Old Testament writings sacred to the Jews.

562514FEFE25400EBF063BD5B8A23550.description: The Bible is inerrant in matters of Revelation and faith: because God is the author of Scripture, all the religious truths that God intends to reveal concerning our salvation are true; this attribute is called “inerrancy” (see DV, no. 11; CCC, no. 107).

E57A710AEECD4CD89AB97DA4D5F1BA4A.description: Because the human authors needed to use the language and thinking of their time, we need to study the conditions and use of language in the context of their time and understand what they intended to communicate, remembering that these human authors might not have been conscious of the deeper implications of what God wanted to communicate (CCC, nos. 106, 108-114).

65FF431FF4D049158A0771BE9A2F5981.description: Since God inspired the biblical writers, he is the author of Scripture (CCC, nos. 105-106, 136).

6D54ED9D3D0545818002D7489569DDBA.description: Inspiration is the gift of the Holy Spirit by which a human author was able to write a biblical book which really has God as the author and which teaches faithfully and without error the saving truth that God willed to be consigned to us for our salvation (CCC, nos. 105, 135).

384CED886D4641EF8E50A962BD68915B.description: he Deposit of Faith and the role of the Church (CCC, nos. 84-95, 98-100).

82F76141853E46FF8FE088FCA2B18BB2.description: The relationship between Tradition and Sacred Scripture (CCC, nos. 80-83, 97).

1850EEA9BBA7442FAAABBEFE89048FB1.description: The transmission of Divine Revelation (CCC, nos. 74-95).

CF72E9981EE34CF2B239E5CC23AE5936.description: Jesus Christ, the first and the last, the definitive Word of Revelation, the one to whom all Scripture bears witness, is God’s only Son (CCC, nos. 65-67, 73, 101-104, 134, 423).

D2358878432B446F95034F51FE0D9467.description: Preparation through John the Baptist (CCC, nos. 523, 717-720).

BB57FBCB427C48A692D375E19641A699.description: Scripture as a divinely inspired record of God’s Revelation in history (CCC, nos. 54-64, 70- 72).

9C62980CD21847AEAD838B7A47371BC5.description: Contemporary arguments based on the human person’s opening to truth, beauty, moral goodness, freedom, voice of conscience (CCC, no. 33).

AF1A0A1CB5BF4D0BB4AEE85E174C49CD.description: Vatican I: we can grasp with certainty the existence of God through human reason (CCC, nos. 36-38, 46-47).

A8C0D33FF00245A2BD1AE0065A708120.description: St. Thomas Aquinas and the five proofs for the existence of God.

6AF5B136ECF749D79670D5A29E6A1501.description: Scholastic theology’s arguments for the existence of God (CCC, nos. 31, 34).

6373031456424717854D1B23D003F62F.description: Natural Revelation attested to in Sacred Scripture (CCC, no. 32).

8BF31DA0B36F400ABC1D729C2E429C2F.description: Only in God can lasting joy

7FC5016DE83C41858623DDFC4207F285.description: That longing itself is from God, who desires and initiates a relationship with each person.

19A32758C8DD491AA99F87FADEA207A4.description: Within all people there is a longing for God.

22660F80A4664F5F9091CC9772FC518E.description: The thirst and desire for God (Catechism of the Catholic Church [CCC], nos. 27-30, 44-45, 1718).

8A6658794B57451A8912D909CACD7909.description: How Do We Know About God?
